dcoy4472X4O9VmVw-dc4vA.text: What a delightful setting, in one of the most interesting areas of London, St Katharine's Dock. The floral display is magnificent, and worth a visit for this alone. I often enjoy the friendliness of the staff, and the bustling atmosphere downstairs.The beer is good and prices not too bad. Lots of information and history around the walls.Charles Dickens would have enjoyed visiting here. The 2nd floor restaurant has yet to be encountered, but the pizzas on the first floor were crisp, flavourful and imaginative, too big for my friend, but good value and a beautiful view. I could imagine Charles, if he was still around, quipping that 'with 9000 Pizzerias in New York alone,an American could rarely find a better setting than this.'

Hc_dl8bW5uCZhUfV5j43FQ.text: I absolutely love the Dickens Inn! The food and service are always outstanding! Perfect place for a romantic meal and also a big meal for a group. Superb location as St Katherines Dock is beautiful at anytime of the year. This place is even more special for me as it's where I met my now husband and where he also took me before proposing on the deck on a boat moared in St Katherine's Dock.

pabXMvtX-Re_MK7Xnbt2og.text: Duck pizza? Rather good, I think they called it Anatro pizza. It was like thai style and pretty good, but pricey, prob cus of beautiful location overlooking a small pier and rich boats near the London Bridge and Thames river. Everyone else got other random pizzas which they all liked. Can't complain, it's just high quality pizza. Not really worth it though only because it's London and you could eat other things (unless u need a pizza fix then I recommend it).

TUpDVoEEmxuDL8-ZmgVE0g.text: This pub, on the edge of St. Katherine's Dock, is a wonderful summer watering hole, overlooking the most elegant boats London has to show. There is nice decking outside, and a huge amount of inside space. The management has tried to keep the traditional feel inside, although this is only partially achieved.The menu looks pretty standard pub grub, perhaps even good, but I have not had the pleasure of digging in. All in all, hard to surpass for a sunny summer Sunday.

5tgATJ4QmrL-EVwvHfSapA.text: Nice pub. Restaurant part do nice burgers send steaks. Good wine selection. Beautifull view on the docks.

2m0n14nBliqMBKh7B49-Yw.text: This is a strange place, with an olde worlde exterior and a warehouse like interior right in the middle of St Katherine's docks. It's a safe choice for a post-work drink with plenty of space for large groups. Beers & wines are generally decent & well-kept if a little expensive (albeit not for St Katherine's docks). If the weather's decent, the outside seating area is quite pleasant. As others have commented, it could be a great place with a little refurbishment and a bit more effort.

KIi-oGBtXeiX8I92t7LWkw.text: Came here after walking around Tower Hill with friends and "HAD to try" this pizza place according to one of them. Pizza here comes in 4 different sizes including a personal pizza just for yourself. A little bit pricey for pizza though if you ask me. Expect to spend about £15 or more for pizza and a drink. yikes! My friend and I shared an Anatra, which I could have lived without, but duck on a pizza sounded interesting. The other guys' pizzas looked better: Quatro Fromaggi, Sorrento, and the Piccante. Too bad we didn't get one of those instead... =(

WhlINC7F5pgGM7XFNn7_4A.text: We stopped in here for a quick evening meal after going to the Tower. The pizza we ordered was great, really tasty & served by staff that were pleasant. A lovely spot to watch the boats and enjoy a drink with friends. The only downside to our visit would be that its looking a little bit old & tired!

MBifc8O3NLAzRnkhGaLQYA.text: fourth visit to the Dickens Inn now and I think the best thing about this place is where it is. In the middle of St. Katherine's dock. An amazing setting amongst the posh yachts of London. The place itself is also a really nice building but I think it just suffers from it's own success. It needs a really good clean and repaint for one. The service has never been anything particularly good. They always seem overstressed, overworked and really not wanting to be there. The pizzas are really worth a visit. It;s just a shame that the management realise what potential they are sat on and start investing in some customer service training and some redecoration as then it really would be a destination venue.

PZbZRNljuONB3wCII0AqOw.text: After walking what seemed like miles I finally managed to find this bar,and what a pleasant place to visit.great service was provided,and the ale in this case London Pride was in perfect condition.the atmosphere was excellent.and its a great place to visit on a summers afternoon.

AX6E0lvYv2rJchQDisjm9w.text: It seems almost everyone likes this place except me.I think it's pretty rubbish.It smells really nasty downstairs, like they've been cleaning it with wet rags that never see the light of day or get dried out.People think it's a quaint traditional place but it's fake. The building is maybe 20 years old and only the facade is made up of wooden beams giving the feel of it being ye olde Dickens Inn.Given the lovely surroundings, it's a shame all the seating is inside in a dark and dingy environment.

TB2_MP6X7sLavDDyJSnScw.text: Amazing pizza, affordable prices, service leaves a lot to be desired..  Great views though

aTvTrkgwGAPXbcwK2zRosQ.text: We love the pub culture in the U,K., and wish we had it in the U.S.  In our week here we have been in several good pubs. This looked to be another one. After 4.5 hours touring the Tower of London, we needed to sit down and have some food. We immediately looked for a pub. This place was warm on a blustery, rainy day, and looked promising. Good atmosphere, good beer and hard cider. We opted to split the "ultimate" fish and chips. The mushy peas were good ( so says my husband as I don't eat them), the chips were great, but the fish...not so much. Batter was doughy and not very crispy. A third of the fish was mushy and inedible. When we ordered we made it clear we were splitting the order. When it was delivered we asked for an extra plate and utensils. After five minutes I located the waitress and asked again. Her English seemed limited. She didn't understand what I wanted until I showed her another fork. We had time constraints and had to move on. A disappointment after all the great pub experiences we have had.

Iv9AlEbqZ6AeIi6aFMCNKQ.text: Absolutely great! A pub with a 4 floors structures with a overview on St.Katherine's dock. Service and products well managed and at the right price. Fascinating the speed with which they serve clients! Very well done

RZamjrFdu44OHDDqPDMc-Q.text: Dickens Inn, the best watering hole in London situated right alongside St. Katherine's Dock. I've been here a few times now and it seems as if every time I come here it's Pimm's O'Clock. They make the best Pimm's cocktail in all of London, and trust me, I've nearly tried them all! Their outdoor patio is huge, great place to relax and meet a few mates. If you're worried you're going to miss a match while sitting outside no need to worry, you can sit in the bar and soak up your share of whatever sport is on as they have a few televisions spaced through the bar. Serving up your typical pub food, the Fish and Chips is by far the best thing on the menu.

zj8ZFJkvqjgtrmippxdsJg.text: We opted to go here when we ran out of options.  We tried the chicken pannini which was forgettable and we also had the fish and chips.  IT was quite expensive, 13 pounds, for just one cod and it tasted ordinary.  It was good, but it left a bad taste in my mouth by being so much money.

bQ3lCY2WSe6xZiehUxXMMA.text: Nice restaurant at St. Catherine's Dock.  Good food.  Friendly staff and service.  You may be able to catch the view of the Tower Bridge opening from your seat.

jwDif7gT9W216AtpmDuSTA.text: My Bulgarian parents came to visit me and we decided to take them to this London landmark. It's all about location, charm, cosiness and athmosphere. Food and drinks are more expensive than in most other pubs but you pay for the view you enjoy while sitting at a window table on one of the upper floors. We had some glasses of high quality Chilean Chardonnay and French Rose as well as several pints of Guiness. Luckily me managed to order some crisps not to drink on empty stomachs. That is where the fun ended. We treid to order more drinks and food but it had gotten very busy and we could not attract any of the staff attentition. My boyfreind went four times to the bar but staff just pretended to not notice him. We spent an hour and a half in the pub and no one came to collect the empty glasses from our table or, at least check on how we were doing and believe me, we weren't a quiet and unnoticeable company.The funniest part of our trip was that despite this being Dad's second visit to London, the first time he came here in 1998,  he was taken to... the Dickens Inn (again). He said that the place does not look as charming as it was 16 years ago (even though smoking indoor is prohibited now). The hanging baskets and all the cuteness outside were all there but he remembers smoked ducks hanging from the ceiling above the bar on the first floor, making the place feel like an inn back in the old times. He had been there during the week and the staff had been more attentive.So overall I was not impressed with the place in terms of service but I was comforted by their choice for music and the Foo Fighters playing out loud!

4execk9ZxZjbSwoY2XSWEQ.text: Large portions and decent quality food.  Service was quick and polite even though they were packed on a Saturday night.  My parents and I ate on the top floor (British pub food) but the bar on the first level and the pizza place on the second level both looked busy too.  Very convenient location if you're staying on Tower Hill.  Cute exterior.

1v6dRJunVvEhEZYR90walg.text: I was enjoying some nice al fresco beers with my mates on Islington Green, and the next thing I remember, the group decided to get up and walk towards the City to find a pub. We somehow ended up at the Dickens Inn... and I have to say, it was not worth the walk. This place is massive. And from what I've seen, it's quite popular with workers from the City. Popular to the point of being obnoxiously crowded. The Dickens inn is aesthetically pleasing. There are nice flowers covering the railings and lining the outdoor area. And it is quite nice to enjoy a beer in the shadow of Tower Bridge. Yet, that is about all there is to say on atmosphere. Its one of those pubs that is too big for its own good. It may be able to serve a lot more customers, but it looses its personality along the way. Bar staff was really friendly, and its not an awful place to watch a football match. However, the beer selection leaves much to be desired. The draught list is little more than Star and Kronenbourg. In my humble opinion, the best beer on tap at the Dickens Inn is London Pride (not bad by any means, but nothing special). Independently, the Dicken's Inn is not a bad place by any measure. Yet, when you compare it to the high quality of pub that is available to you in London if you just make an effort, it definitely falls short.

TOLcFA7qEmF6NewUCzqAWg.text: Nice setting with a view to the yacht harbor, variety of beers is good - though we did not eat here. The gents bathroom have an awful stench- could be more clean.

HpteC66qjTXXpf_nZmxkBg.text: Food was okay, but atmosphere earned an extra star!

G1ODmRCd3hGxoU8gJHsetw.text: I'd only been to St Katharine's Docks once before, and that was years ago, even before I had moved to London. So I couldn't remember what pubs and restaurants were there. I certainly didn't recall the Dickens Inn - a huge creaky-looking drinking establishment in the corner, overlooking one of the docks. It was a gorgeous evening, so we thought our chances of bagging a table on one of the balconies were slim. Amazingly there was a free table straight away, and we couldn't believe our luck, looking out over the water as we sipped our drinks. OK, so the food isn't anything special, but that's not what we were there for. It was quick and served with a smile and a bit of friendly banter. So all in all a solid choice if you're in the area, and perfect on a mild, summer's evening.

euO4Hu9qXnZBQ8C2vg2FlA.text: Pizza was awful. Service so "computer says no" we resented the 12.5% service charge added on and complained to the manager. By all means, enjoy a pint & the view here, but eat elsewhere. There are so many other nice options in London worth spending your hard earned cash.

7jeIG2e6FkupPn3D-GkY2Q.text: It's been a year since I've been here but since there were no reviews....Absolutely love this place!  It's in St. Katherine's Dock, across from Tower of London.  Actually been here a few times; each visit was great!Service is good even when packed, and I do mean packed.  It's close to a lot of office buildings so happy hour here is bumping.Guinness is poured perfectly & the Pimm's Cup, outstanding.  Great food, good vibe, great crowd & great bar staff.Each time I'm in London, this will definately be one of my pubs to visit.

T5frVb2AH9gu8Xnx2oYVEA.text: Situated in the historic St Kathryn's Dock in a converted Tea Warehouse this is a busy early evening and weekend pub and restaurant. It has a couple of restaurants one serving Pizzas etc., and the other a more extensive menu. The was the first time I tried Ostrich and was pleasantly surprised. (By the way the picture is the view from the Dickens Arms over St Kathryn's Dock.

photos.caption: Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom

HSkJIxHKo8yQx4PKIIRiPQ.text: Finding restaurants can be just like house-hunting, it's all about location. Nestled amongst the super yachts The Dickens Inn looks dubious from the outside but is actually a great place for drinks and/or a meal. There's some quite pricey places in St Katherine's docks but a pizza from their upstairs pizza restaurant is reasonably priced with a cheap and cheerful wine list to match. We sat next to the window with a great view of the water, next time I hope to nab a spot on the balcony.

photos.caption: Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom

_A1RUvvMriIUsd4gJsLzVQ.text: This place can divide opinion, which I can totally understand why, having come away with different opinions myself on different visits. To some it might seem like an old fashioned London pub, in quite an idyllic location. To another observer it might seem like a tourist trap that doesn't need to try too hard as it will be busy whatever happens. I have enjoyed visits here in the distant past, I remember enjoying cheap and decent pizza upstairs on one occasion for example, but this rating is based on a recent visit (as it should be, because places can change) where the service seemed fairly distracted and the ale was not of a particularly good quality (you may as well not bother serving it if you're not going to serve it properly). Tables had also been left uncleaned for a while too. Some sporting event (it was rugby I think, so I didn't care) had just finished, which may be some sort of excuse. The pub has no link to Dickens whatsoever, I figure that is just a name that would appeal to tourists. I mean it's only about 20 odd years old. The building used to be a brewery elsewhere before being plonked down in the docks.

8KH2S0DtnPa5p1xkqTnPNg.text: Lovely place to go in the summer especially. Service can sometimes be a little odd (I'm often served by a trainee barman for some reason) but is generally polite. Large place but the lovely outdoor tables get snapped up quickly so get there early (or prepare to spend time hovering) if you want a good seat. Food has also been lovely on the occasions I've been there. I once arrived with a group of friends on a Sunday afternoon when most of the roasts had sold outbut we managed to get a few bowls of roast potatoes and gravy which were amazing!

xUb1deGQ5AMl1FwhvqtkrA.text: I've been coming here for years.  Whenever I'm in the area, this is my choice of pub.It has a great view over St Katherines Dock. It's mock Victorian decor, adds the environment. They have a wide selection of beers, and standard pub fayre, any tourist to London would expect.The only downside I have, is that the last few times I have been, I seem to arrive just after a coach load of tourists get there, all ordering coffees of various types.  This leads to a long wait for a pint!

photos.caption: Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom. The Dickens in at St Katherines Dock

C1qNy-AZTRUMmKHZkCaTaA.text: Right by the riverside against a great view, in an old rustic 18th century converted warehouse, what else do you want? It had the perfect atmosphere, warm, cosy, sensible people and it may be a bit tattered but it adds to the historical feel of it and I wouldn't change it at all. In fact I loved the whole building in was in and the whole location with the view of the boats, all very romantic. For a Saturday it wasn't even too pack as it is in quite a secluded area which is perfect for a tourist location, not a big fan of loud busy places.Service was also very friendly provided by a lady who was more than accommodating, helping us book via Toptable on last minute terms to help me collect my 100 points. Also very smiley and genuine which ticked points for good service.As it was the three of us we ordered the buffalo wings, olives and a medium pizza, half Florentine and meat feast. It was surprisingly large for a medium pizza & could easily feed 4. The wings were perfectly tender, succulent and big, in a really moreish sauce that wasn't too sweet & finger lickin good.  Olives were garlicky which we all loved although quite small in portion for its price.I must say the Florentine was slightly disappointing. Eggs were rubbery because they came boiled which is not how a Florentine should be done and they were quite bland overall. The meat feast however was delicious, packed with flavour,a good variety and quantity of toppings, good thick layer stringy cheese for the perfect pizza bite. if you're looking for a light pizza this place is not it. Food was slightly overpriced but that's predictable for  the location it's in and the novelty of having such a large pizza called the 'beast' served on a lifted platter. I suppose I would recommend for a special occasion especially in the location it's in and if you've got a group of people. Just make sure Florentine is not one of the pizza option you're picking and it should be fine and enjoyable. Wash it down with two shots of Malibu and coke like I did and it will be even better ;)

photos.caption: Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom. The Beast- Half a Florentine and half a Meat Feast

pEfqU_6bPH8Y71KsxorVkg.text: This pub is MASSIVE!! It has 3 floors with the upper two floors serving as restaurants and the bottom floor is your bog standard pub. I've only been here once and I sat outside but I liked the atmosphere. It was very busy, mainly as it was a Friday night after work so people were winding down. We ordered a pitcher of Pimms which came to around £18 and had fresh cucumber, mint, lemon and strawberries in which was lovely and refreshing for a warm, balmy evening. And I love St Katharine's Dock - where it is located. Such a lovely area, especially on a hot summer evening.

m3cADpz4hMUYLu4uqBjP9A.text: Dickens Inn building is a converted 18th century converted victorian warehouse next to the riverside with a great view of the docks. The hanging baskets and tattered feel all work very well to build an interesting atmosphere. Unfortunately the pub inside is completely let down and it destroys the whole atmosphere so it does only worth sitting outside.Food wise i have only tried the pizza which was quite nice but the "beast" is not sufficient to share between 4 people and the price was just ridiculous £50 + 12.5% service charge.It probably works out better if you get 4 small pizzas instead of the beast both price wise and slices per person ratio. I wouldn't recommend the desserts/puddings as they are surprisingly small & blunt.I wouldn't make a specific trip just to visit this place but if you are around tower bridge and you can secure a seat at the balcony it is a much better option than the rest of the pubs in the area.

Ku5BMZeU8X9l8uvGI3jhpA.text: Dickens Inn is made up of three floors of restaurants. First floor is a lounge, second floor is a pizza place, the third is a bar and grill. Prices goes up as the floors go up. The food was okay, nothing special. I had the Dickens Inn Chicken & Chips £14.50, which comprised of chargrilled,  jerk-seasoned half chicken, chips & home-made slaw. The chicken was not very flavourful but juicy and not dry. I subbed the chips with onion rings, and I was super happy with the rings. My boyfriend got the chargrilled 28 Day Matured Rib-Eye Steak for £18.50 with home made onion rings, chunky chips, flat mushroom & tomato. The steak was cooked right, the flat mushroom was flavourless. Everything tasted better with the Pepper Sauce but it was £1.00 extra.The service was great, with the exception that they kept trying to get us to add more food all the time, which was strange. Otherwise, we loved their service.It's okay. Not great, but not too shabby.

El1XzSmLuhEQRD39zkLQIg.text: Home to St Katherine's Dock this really is a hidden gem that not many people know about. I would certain go out of the way to find if that part of the river. It has a fab décor from outside with leafy terraces. I had a pizza inside which was good and a good beer selection but this is all about wandering there on a nice sunny day and camping out to enjoy the buzz and exterior view. it's certainly unique. (as of May 20th 2015) A good mixed grill. A solid 6/10 Chips were highlight. Rump steak was not bad. Gammon good. Sausages I didn't like. But lovely pub though. Terraced in St Katherine's Dock this is a great place for a date or to show friends visiting. Perfect for summers day and pumps up stars because of that alone.

gB-PeAJ6FEx0MMjFOP0fMQ.text: Meh...close to Tower Bridge and The Tower of London which is a plus. Good just ok and it's self serve. Tunes playing in the Tavern were quite good though!

photos.caption: Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom. Tavern at The Dickens Inn

JfESR7tt_oqS_2tWBkMBIg.text: When you are craving a proper pub lunch around Tower Bridge, the choices are limited. We thought we had struck gold when we saw the Dickens Inn, but it was just average.Firstly, no Sundays roasts downstairs, only up in the Grill upstairs. As we were sat in the ample garden area outside, we settled on various items from the limited menu.Food was ok, although the hunters chicken had no bbq sauce, and there wasn't very much hot food available for people who can't eat gluten.Oh, and one more thing.Sausage and mash should come with peas!

C5XLX_Bk13Jc4VCkwj56bw.text: Admittedly, I only drank on the first floor here, but was far from impressed.  It has no soul, and for £5/pint, the prices were astronomical.It feels like a Whetherspoons, or other pub that's meant to be "country" but is actually owned by a giant chain.The toilets were dirty (with the weirdest toilet eats?!), beer (vs ale) selection was pretty poor, and it generally didn't have the kind of vibe we like in a pub.  I can imagine the Dickens being much nicer on a summer evening, but on this cold wet rainy January night we only stayed for the one pint our wallets could afford, and moved on.

kXdI0aDpj43tITchRz2IOQ.text: Clearly a tourist pub which has some ok beer and ok wine at high prices. The number and variety of customers make up for the atmosphere, service is slow and lacking in personality and the food is bog standard with a lot of stuff heated in the microwave. The best thing about this place is the big outdoor seating and standing area in the summer.

RlMJfhHkYLLBnad_oq21nA.text: Cool pub in a great area. Watched game 1 of the rugby world cup here and it was nice and rowdy. good beer selection and a great place to watch any rugby or football game in london. I'd come back

Jlj7knDvQGUxKioGZaLF-Q.text: Came to Dickens inn pizza restaurant on the first floor. Looks lovely from the outside and great location, but is definitely over charging and under performing on food as a result. Pizzas were hugely over priced and average, chicken wings came out cold, wedges were tiny in size and portion, service was slow despite not being that busy. Would not return here except for a drink downstairs.

7w13ohAYWz1Yhx39mMYX0Q.text: Unfortunately quite a sub par experience for me here, decor aside, most of the features were disappointing. The pizza were not amazingly large (i.e. of corse the medium one are really large but they also cost quite some cash for a pizza). The wine was (or should I say, were) awful, and yet we tried three or four different. The service was not specifically friendly, not very helpful. The pizza sauce was mere oil and I was given tabasco when I asked for a "more spicy" one. Finally they were not able to give us suitable expense bills, so if you go here on a business trip, be prepared not to be able to split large pizzas and other things.

V8guQeXF3YNsub0pdKT2AQ.text: Expensive pints, reasonable service. Not noisy for a pub, which I prefer and has a few large screens showing football.The pizza downstairs are quite good. Or if you prefer grilled food, you can order it upstairs.Best come during the summer.

nZ8Yciss6XICD25xYj0hlA.text: If you're looking for a place with authentic old world feel, you know the sort -- rustic, lots of old wood, exposed beams and bricks and masonry, some polished brass, a fireplace, smoke stains -- then this spot is dead on target.  Stumbled across it whilst walking about the docks, looking for a cool spot to have lunch after spending most of the day at The Tower and were we ever pleased.  I mean, what's not to like about a place that has Fullers ESB on tap?Eh, seriously, the atmosphere is totally great, especially given that we ate outside on a gorgeous sunny afternoon with a view of the docks and all the goings on.Food was pretty good:  I had a steak sandwich, which, while a bit chewy, was amazingly flavorful.  Wife had a chicken pie, which was truly delicious:  Creamy, salty, great smashed potatoes as the cover, and plentiful chunky pieces o' chicken.  Son had the fish and chips:  Whole fish, breaded and fried, crispy, not overly seasoned, with buttery smooth cod encased within.  Fries were, according to him, quite good, as he was unwilling to share.Service was fine and professional, if a bit brusque; not unfriendly, mind you, perfectly polite, just, well, you know, they were there to work, thank you very much.Look, I know I'm a tourist, but this place just felt so authentic and was quite simply stunning from the outside, didn't disappoint once in, and we were gonna like it even if they'd served us the bottom from a hobo's shoe.  Which they didn't.Looking for a place to hang, drink, and see the docks?  I can't imagine it gets much better than this.

hRxfW2A-9gkgWCrObtHybw.text: Had drinks here yesterday afternoon, good service, loads of space inside  - found table. Drinks on pricey side, but not overly so for central London. Nice vibe, fantastic outside space. Would come again.

pbtobFz-7zSSuxRuCvQxww.text: Another great pub with a historical feel. I love the decking seating where you can sit on a sunny day and just look out onto the docks. Great location and a great Spot for drinks with friends

YoPKmIK2TCatuLHYIhWyqg.text: Our first night out in London and we were wandering all over and stumbled upon this 18th century converted victorian warehouse at St. Katherine's Dock which is rather picturesque from the outside and resembled an old ship from the inside which all added to the experience! They boast a wide selection of beers and regular pub fare which seems to be the food of London!  We had the buffalo wings, olives and bread, pulled pork sandwich and margherita pizza.  We kept it simple having experienced british cuisine before we knew to stick to food that most resembled what we enjoyed at home!  The food was good and of course expensive because everything in London in, but it was an enjoyable experience on a memorable night!  Try to avoid the takeaway as they call takeout as it is quite expensive with the VAT.

5CpU9213m8-XMkjXZZ5WMQ.text: Looks great from the outside. Food was average when we finally got it. Waitstaff acted like they didn't want to be there. I would not recommend this place to any of my friends. There are many more places around the dock to spend your pounds at.

g76BNhwnY8YUAOCTt1bUpg.text: An average pub in a pretty setting.  The outdoor balconies looking over St Katherine's Docks are lovely, but the pub inside lets it down.  It feels a little bit like a Wetherspoons. The only vaguely good beer they have on tap is Meantime's Yakima Red. The pizzas in the upstairs restaurant are okay, but expensive.  If it wasn't for the view, I wouldn't be back, but it's a place I occasionally end up when showing friends visiting London the area around Tower Bridge.

xY5334XAB2XH2ITRxyQKAQ.text: Recommended by the concierge at our hotel. Very good food and reasonable prices. Sat on the third floor balcony overlooking the tower bridge.Very nice experience.

M_96gmYrlnJVPWDvQ6sELA.text: This is one of our favorite stops when in London.  We've eaten outside, in the downstairs pub and on the second floor.  Good food reasonably priced. Nice setting on the marina. It's a short walk from the Tower.

photos.caption: Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom

TBKLs_KxQ4zagujr5L5Ylg.text: This is such a cute place. I love the concept of having different cuisine on each floor. My friend and I chose the 2nd, which is a pizzeria. She got the margherita pizza and I got the mushroom risotto. DE-LISH. You get the view of the water too, which is a plus. Seems to be the place everyone pops into after work for a pint. Flower boxers decorate the exterior, along with Strings of British flags.

xPwdfSxpXkE9lEydYRtnYw.text: very basic. i've had far superior experiences with fish and chips at home. the dining sits in a pretty dock, and their staff are well-mannered. i just don't have much to brag about their food. this place was recommended to us by a local my friend and i met in paris, but i think we could have done better. the reviews of this place.. they do not lie. sorry!

photos.caption: Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom. menu, 03/06/18
Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom. menu, 03/06/18

HCyWbla6TDOxSa_TmKRqpg.text: A tricky one to rate this! I love the quaint, olde worlde look of the place, esp the traditional wooden beams and gorgeous hanging baskets bursting with bright flowers on each level. I stopped by for drinks and dinner with a friend visiting from NYC (she chose it). It took me a while to find the pizzeria she was talking about but after wandering through a pretty unappealing pub area downstairs I found the gang on the top floor.The service was painfully slow when you wanted to order, but they were also nicely flexible (oblivious?!) about the group size ranging from 4 initially to 9 through the evening as people rocked up gradually after work (the lawyers last!). I enjoyed the goat's cheese pizza with red onion, and you could tell the base was freshly made which was a big plus considering it was a little heavy on the dough in the dough-to-topping ratio. The sides and other bits I munched (/stole) from others were also nice enough, but I thought quite pricey for what they were.It's in a great spot by the docks and I can see myself drifting back here if I was avoiding the chains nearby, but I can't say I'm in any rush as it's just a-ok for this price point.

NwQ9IQir9sUFOcseflTPPA.text: Ate here yesterday with friends. It was freezing outside and just as cold inside. Apparently this building doesn't have heat.The beer was good but the food was less than mediocre.15£ for crappy fish and chips8£ for a fish sandwich that was mostly bread. The menu says it comes with onion rings. Apparently there were 2 technically it was ring(s)...PleaseDidn't experience any rude staff since no one ever came to talk to us...Don't recommend

G7otmnUup6tazfXlrZG_UQ.text: The building was a gorgeous wood building with flowers all over it.   We at on the top floor with a view of the marina, peaceful!  The building was built in the late 1700s as a warehouse and you could see the exposed rafters - I just loved the look of the place.   Mama and I had fish and chips - which she LOVED and Jack had a burger which was also good.  The service was inattentive and not great, but other than that we loved the restaurant.  I know service in general is slower in Europe than the US, but this wasn't slow - it was bad.  They need to improve the wait staff and it would be a killer restaurant.  I just loved the feel of it.

RNoCz_ADpuprmmESh9dyow.text: This was the only restaurant in London that we visited twice during our seven day stay. The pizza was really good and the crust was exceptional making it the best pizza (and one of the best meals) we had during our trip. We ate on the balcony overlooking St. Katherine' s Dock which really added to the experience. The beast worked out well for the four of us - two adults and two kids (under 11) - and they were able to split the toppings the way we wanted - half Parma and half Margherita.The tavern on the first floor had a great selection and although each floor had its own restaurant, they said you could bring the pizza down if you wanted to eat it there.

photos.caption: Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom. Dickens Inn at night
Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom. Parma pizza and anti pasta with a Meantime lager.

Mw42GSBQa11TNKfC_G_3MQ.text: Uhhh so frustrating!!!! This place should be 5 stars, but the service is so unbelievably bad, I had to knock it down to 3 stars. It took over 20 minutes for the waiter to even come over to us to take our drink order. Then, they messed up our food order... twice! It wasn't even busy! We ordered the brownie and ice cream dessert and it only came with a brownie. When we asked for the ice cream, he said "oh, no ice cream, sorry." What a joke! He could have told us that before we ordered it. He also could have offered to take it off of our bill, especially since it was brought to our table and we had to point out the mistake. He knew there was a mistake, but he was obviously hoping we wouldn't catch it. We will come again, but we now know not to have the same waiter.

NS_dWvPTTutJm3rTiCtTZA.text: Decent pub. Can't decide if it's high end or chavvy...Really nice location. Really big. Lots of drink selection. That said, it kind of has no soul for a pub with this awesome a building and this location... I would expect more. The beer is ok, but I have had complaints from friends so it's not consistent. Genuinely, there aren't many better options in the area (that I know of) so I would come here if you're nearby. But your socks will stay decidedly non blown off.

photos.caption: Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom. The view

8fBV3sVfkLYTfOHaP1kDNw.text: Great first impressions, well presented with all the flower boxes and overlooking St Katherine's Dock. Inside is quite large, with different food options on every floor, with a pizza restaurant, steak restaurant and pub grub on the ground floor. It was really busy when my friend and I visited as part of the pub was closed off for a wedding party. We found a table in the main bar on the ground floor and ordered some food. We both went for the ultimate beer battered fish and chips as we were really hungry (£14.95). The presentation of the food was really nice, but we didn't think the portion was any bigger than expected and found we had essentially spent the extra £2.00 on 1 piece of bread and some curry sauce! The food was enjoyable but nothing particularly special, it wasn't very hot when it  arrived and after hunting down some salt in the bar, were even colder when we got stuck in. Drinks weren't the cheapest, but I guess that is the area. I would still return for a drink around St Katherine's Dock, but might try the food on the upper floors instead. I would probably rate the overall experience a 3.5/5.

photos.caption: Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom. Ultimate fish & chips
Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom. Pretty exterior

sjc8QF1jzJsBHfuYXSgowQ.text: I love this place and wish that there were more around. The pub has a wonderfully fresh appearance from outside, matches with a wooden (medieval styled) interior. It homes a number of different cuisines, with plenty of choice on drinks. It's in a great location and has lovely views, especially when sunny. Would recommend this place to locals and traveller's alike.

photos.caption: Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom

NQE5gcTi0ygaPRTnJ469vA.text: This unique pub located at the St katherine dock, it is also nearby the Tower Bridge. This unique building is a 18th century building with a nice location setting and a lovely yacht views opposite .They used the Ground floor as a bar; first floor served the pizza and second floor serve as a grill restaurant. You can find a lovely views at the linear balcony dining area on 1st and 2nd floor; with chunky timber construction and hanging flowers and plants. it often attract a lot of tourist coming here. Pizza menu is simple and have three selection, you can go for small, large and feast size. Large size of pizzas only cost less than £30. We had ordered one large cajun chicken pizza and one large spicy chorizo pizza which is perfectly done and delicious.. Alongside with these pizzas, we also have salad with melon and bread with olives, all is good. This is such a cool place to have your meal if you are not far from tower bridge. It is highly recommended and not to miss to visit it if you are tourist around that area.

photos.caption: Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom

FJhEMOk0CCMjVYDTY-HerA.text: Had lunch at the pub with the wife and kids. Found out from a local that you have to goto the bar area to order food. Had service staff walk by many times, but didn't say a word. When ordering at the bar expect to be ignored if you aren't white. Standing in line right in front of the server and she will ignore you and help other patrons. Complained to the other staff members and was finally helped by someone else. Location was good next to the boats and the patrons inside were nice. Food was decent, but expect to wait for a long time. There's a monitor with orders on it at the bar so to check on your order, it's best to go there since no one else will help you. If you need to speak to servers about getting more napkins or anything else, well good luck.

DlGKJY4hZfnsOdiAKt857A.text: Interesting concept but the services is extremely slow. It was even mostly empty at 4:00 when we arrived for a snack. The waiter spent his time shuffling chairs around. Food tasted ok.

6qOSKzjNhvzl65xpc3KrDw.text: Came here with a friend for a drink and dinner.  We started off on the first floor pub which was busy but fun.  Service behind the bar was leisurely, but you'd get your drink eventually.  After a drink we headed up stairs to the second floor for some pizza.  Growing up in Chicago I was unsure of how this pizza would stack up (I wasn't expecting or desiring deep dish).  We ordered a large Goat's cheese (which came with, red onion, spinach and garlic oil), and it was really quite good.  Very thing crust with a nice bit of chewiness to it, not floppy.  Close to a NYC style pie.  The beers were cold and the pizza hot and bubbly.  You can't go wrong!

C_N4HAEQrj-LevweVej_yA.text: This place has an awesome location and my airbnb was right across the square. With a name like 'Dickens Inn' we had to give to try. The place has a cool atmosphere and the patrons were all enjoying themselves. The staff didn't seem to care if we were there or not. The nachos were decent and the beer selection was OK.

cyrghQJY2Ac-zJxSx2JWGA.text: Had a great time watching rugby and having a pint....or twoGreat service and loved to the upstairs for delicious food

i0K7Ru149hDrkC66XxcJsg.text: I've been to The Dickens Inn a few times. It's in a very cute location, and looks gorgeous with the hanging baskets lining the outside of the three story rustic 18th century building.Last night I stopped off there for a drink in the outside section before going for dinner. The drinks are reasonably priced and it's a nice location, close to Tower Bridge. I've previously indulged in the huge pizzas they served there. Worth a try in your in the area and hungry.I've also been there for a couple work functions - they have a large room available for hire which is slightly to the side of the main bar and seating area.A very nice place to go, but I personally wouldn't make a specific trip there if you're not already heading to that part of London.

photos.caption: Photo of The Dickens Inn - London, United Kingdom

Dqr0iVROEI_p6saf2pq47A.text: Located right next to St. Katherine's dock, the Dickens Inn enjoys a fine tranquil location away from all the hustle and bustle of central London. The Dickens is a large pub with three levels and is spectacularly adorned with numerous hanging baskets. It has a lovely historic look and feel.  Inside, there are the traditional low beam ceilings you would expect in such a building and wooden flooring. The Dickens promotes itself as very much a pub/restaurant. I would recommend the pizza!Worth a visit, especially if you desire a quiet pleasant waterside oasis while you enjoy your lunch.
